exercise.rubric: Write the third person singular forms of these verbs.
Are these spellings right (R) or wrong (W)? When you have checked your answers, correct any wrong spellings.

question.text: I’m <item>siting</item> at the back of the train.
She’s <item>showing</item> the new design to her manager.
My sister is always <item>beatting</item> me at tennis.

feedback.desc: 347.1–6 For B, in American English traveling is the normal spelling.

exercise.rubric: Say the words aloud. One word in each list has a different vowel sound. Which word?
Are these present tense forms used correctly: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ‘The kettle <item>boils</item>.’ ‘Please take it off the stove.’

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Choose the best reply: A or B.
option: ‘Because I’m only happy when I’m busy.’
‘Because I have to finish my report by the end of this week.’
question.answer: ‘Because I’m only happy when I’m busy.’

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?
Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Which of the answers is/are possible: A, B or both?
question.input_text: ‘Excuse me. How do I get to the station?’
option: ‘<item>You go</item> straight on to the traffic lights, then <item>you turn</item> left.’
‘<item>You’re going</item> straight on to the traffic lights, then <item>you’re turning</item> left.’
question.answer: ‘You go straight on to the traffic lights, then you turn left.’

question.text: A TV chef is describing a recipe as she’s cooking it. Which sentence(s) is/are possible: A, B or both?
option: First <item>I take</item> a bowl and <item>break</item> two eggs into it.
First <item>I’m taking</item> a bowl and <item>am breaking</item> two eggs into it.
question.answer: First I take a bowl and break two eggs into it.

exercise.rubric: Is this exchange right (R) or wrong (W)? When you have checked your answer, correct the exchange if it is wrong.

question.text: ‘How long do you know her?’ ‘I know her since 2014.’

right: ‘How long have you known her?’ ‘I’ve known her since 2014.’
‘How long have you known her?’ ‘I've known her since 2014.’
'How long have you known her?' 'I’ve known her since 2014.'
'How long have you known her?' 'I've known her since 2014.'
How long have you known her? I’ve known her since 2014.
How long have you known her? I've known her since 2014.
‘How long have you known her?’ ‘I have known her since 2014.’
‘How long have you known her?’ ‘I have known her since 2014.’
'How long have you known her?' 'I have known her since 2014.'
'How long have you known her?' 'I have known her since 2014.'
How long have you known her? I have known her since 2014.
How long have you known her? I have known her since 2014.

question.text: Which of the replies is/are correct: A, B or both?
question.input_text: ‘Remember to phone me when you arrive.’

question.text: Which is the best reply: A or B?

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: The summer term <item>will start</item> on April 10th.
Which question(s) is/are correct: A, B or both?
option: What do you do this evening?
What are you doing this evening?
question.answer: What are you doing this evening?

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: It’s going to snow before long.

exercise.rubric: Are the replies correct: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Which of the replies is/are correct?

exercise.rubric: Do the continuations make correct sentences: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ... when there are not enough new houses.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Which of these is more usual: A or B?
option: <item>It says</item> in the instructions that you need two 9-volt batteries.
<item>It’s saying</item> in the instructions that you need two 9-volt batteries.
question.answer: It says in the instructions that you need two 9-volt batteries.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Which of these sports commentaries uses present tenses correctly: A, B or both?
option: ‘Smith <item>passes</item> to Devaney; Harris <item>intercepts</item>. Harris <item>passes back</item> to Simms and Simms <item>shoots</item>!’
‘Oxford <item>are pulling</item> ahead of Cambridge. They<item>’re rowing</item> steadily. Cambridge <item>are looking</item> a bit disorganised.’

question.text: Which question is the more likely response: A or B?
question.input_text: ‘Jake’s just phoned in to say he’s ill.’
option: ‘So <item>who’s going to teach</item> his class this afternoon?’
question.answer: ‘So who’s going to teach his class this afternoon?’

question.text: Which is the best way to end the sentence: A, B or C?
question.input_text: I’m seeing my boss tomorrow and ...
option: ... <item>I’m going to complain</item> about the workload.
question.answer: ... I’m going to complain about the workload.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?
Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: <item>You’re going to take</item> that medicine, whether you like it or not!
<item>You’re taking</item> that medicine, whether you like it or not!

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Don’t phone them now – <item>they’re having</item> dinner.
Don’t phone them now – <item>they’ll be having</item> dinner.
Which is the best way to end the sentence: A, B or C?
question.answer: ... I’ll be lying on the beach.

exercise.rubric: Can expressions A–D end the sentence correctly: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: The builders say they <item>will have</item> finished the roof ...

question.text: ... by the end of the week.
Which is the correct continuation: A or B?
option: Be careful while <item>you’re driving</item> home tomorrow.
Be careful while <item>you’ll be driving</item> home tomorrow.
question.answer: Be careful while you’re driving home tomorrow.

exercise.rubric: Can the verb forms complete the sentence correctly: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: If we <gap/> by lunchtime, we had better hurry.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: <item>I’m going</item> to America about once a month.
<item>We’re going</item> to a lot of concerts these days.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: My job<item>’s getting</item> less and less interesting.
The universe <item>is expanding</item>, and has been since its beginning.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: She doesn’t like to be disturbed when <item>she’s working</item>.
When the mail comes <item>I’m</item> usually <item>having breakfast</item>.

exercise.rubric: What is the difference between these two sentences?

question.input_text:
I look forward to hearing from you.
I’m looking forward to hearing from you.

exercise.answer: The first sentence is more formal than the second.

question.text: Three of these sentences mean more or less the same. Which one is different?
option: <item>Are you going to do</item> the shopping tomorrow?
<item>Will you be doing</item> the shopping tomorrow?
question.answer: Will you do the shopping tomorrow?

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: <item>I’m wanting</item> a taxi to the station now.
I told the receptionist that <item>I was wanting</item> a taxi to the station.
<item>I’ll be wanting</item> a taxi to the station at 6.00 tomorrow morning.
Which of these is/are right: A, B or both?

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Our house <item>is getting</item> new windows this winter.
Our house <item>is going to get</item> new windows this winter.
Their new house <item>is looking</item> over the river.
Their new house <item>is going to look</item> over the river.
What do you think about the use of shall?
question.input_text: The hirer <item>shall be</item> responsible for maintenance of the vehicle.
option: It’s typical of very formal language.
It’s more common in American English than in British English.
question.answer: It’s typical of very formal language.

question.text: What do you think of the future structure in this sentence?
question.input_text: I’m going to be working late tomorrow.

question.text: Choose the best explanation of Anna’s reply.
question.input_text:
joe: Do you think Jack will come to the meeting?
anna: No, he’ll have forgotten.
option: He may remember now, but he’ll forget before the meeting takes place.
